Every time a bee visits a flower, it's not just about pollinationâ€”it's about keeping nature's rhythm alive. Bees are crucial to the health of our gardens, ecosystems, and food production. Without their tireless work, many of the plants we love would struggle to reproduce.

By supporting bee-friendly practices, such as planting a variety of nectar-rich flowers and avoiding harmful pesticides, we help these industrious pollinators continue their vital work. The health of our gardens depends on their visits, and it's up to us to protect them.
Let's do our part by creating environments that support bees and other pollinators. After all, every flower they visit keeps nature's beautiful rhythm in motion.

It's time to rethink how we define progress. Destruction of nature is often seen as growth, but true progress lies in nurturing and protecting what sustains us. Let's make choices that honor the beauty and wisdom of the Earth.

An old tree is a testament to decisions made long before our arrival. Shade, shelter, and cooler air are benefits we enjoy today because someone once took the time to plant and nurture it. Trees teach patienceâ€”they grow slowly but reward generously.

Planting a tree today is an act of kindness toward people we may never meet. It provides future generations with a place to rest, gather, breathe, and find peace outdoors. This single act can shape the character of a landscape for decades or even centuries.
Gardening reminds us that legacy begins with small actions. A seed in the soil becomes a sanctuary tomorrow, extending generosity far beyond our grasp.

I think it's probably time for organized groups to demand very basic statements of commitment to journalism from corporate outletsâ€”and to make clear that if those outlets can't commit to journalism they'll be boycotted.

The head of every corporate media enterprise should be willing to publicly make this commitment: We don't republish or condone slursâ€”implicitly or explicitly. My view is that any corporate media enterprise unwilling to make this commitment publicly should be abandoned by every single viewer it has.

What that looks like is telling cable guests that if they use slurs they won't be asked back. If you call a Democratic politician a Democrat politicianâ€”an old slur that's an allegation of Communism (Google it)â€”you won't be asked back to the show. I've been a journalist for 30+ years and have worked in a newsroom. You have to start with baby steps. An easy baby step to start with is to commit whatever publication you work for to not publish slurs. Slurs are never newsworthy; they're disinformation. Let sources know you won't repeat them.

Corporate journalism must change or die. The first changes need to be smallâ€”or change won't start at all.
